Message.Title: BOYCOTT YAHOO :CRIMINAL MANAGEMENT ENFORCING CENSORSHIP ON BEHALF OF HIGH TREASON CRIMINAL RULERS IN WASHINGTON DC
Message.Msg: #$%$ CENSORSHIP BY YAHOO CROOKS “I believe that banking institutions are more dangerous to our liberties than standing armies.” – Thomas Jefferson If the American people ever allow private banks to control the issue of their currency, first by inflation, then by deflation, the banks…will deprive the people of all property until their children wake-up homeless on the continent their fathers conquered…. The issuing power should be taken from the banks and restored to the people, to whom it properly belongs. – Thomas Jefferson in the debate over the Re-charter of the Bank Bill (1809) Andrew Jackson : Gentlemen, I have had men watching you for a long time and I am convinced that you have used the funds of the bank to speculate in the breadstuffs of the country. When you won, you divided the profits amongst you, and when you lost, you charged it to the bank. You tell me that if I take the deposits from the bank and annul its charter, I shall ruin ten thousand families. That may be true, gentlemen, but that is your sin! Should I let you go on, you will ruin fifty thousand families, and that would be my sin! You are a den of vipers and thieves. DAVID STOCKMAN: We've Been Lied To, Robbed, And Misled

Message.Title: Yahoo Redesigns U.S. Web Search as Mayer Goes After Google
Message.Msg: Yahoo! Inc. redesigned its U.S. Web search as Chief Executive Officer Marissa Mayer works to revive growth at the Internet portal. Search results will now load faster and appear higher on the page, the Sunnyvale, California-based company said today in a statement. The company is also introducing a navigation bar at the top of the page to help users browse other Yahoo sites.

Topic.Title: Yahoo Redesigns U.S. Web Search as Mayer Goes After Google

Message.Msg: Mayer, CEO of the biggest U.S. Web portal since July, is trying to lure users and advertisers back to Yahoo as it chases Google Inc. and Facebook Inc. in the $17.7 billion market for display ads. Mayer has made several acquisitions since taking the helm, including last months’s $1.1 billion agreement to acquire blogging network Tumblr Inc.

Topic.Title: Yahoo Will Be Bought for Over $40 per Share After Alibaba IPO

Message.Msg: You're welcome for the visual. :) I wish this site allowed for private messages as I don't want to spill everything here. Unlike some of the fools that post here (who mindlessly think they are influencing the market up or down at this little observed message board in order to pay for their groceries), I am a long term investor. I never fall in love with a stock or marry it, but when the fundamentals are really good, when the upward potential is high, when a good management team is in control and such, then I'll invest and wait for the payoff. It's worked for me since the 1980's through good times and bad. OK. I will say this: The IPO is already somewhat factored into Yahoo's pricing, but not completely and very little of Yahoo Japan is factored in. Marissa has money to spend and still a little time to PROVE to investors (and to Dan Loeb) she is 1.) mobilizing Yahoo and 2.) monetizing Yahoo. She may escape one more quarter without doing it, but then Loeb and others (like me) will want some scratch for our investment. This is why her own financial "reward" was re-structured around growth rather than profits recently. She has to show some growth by Autumn. But that is a small piece of the puzzle. Alibaba IPO should push Yahoo up over $30 easily with some overshoot and swings thereafter. But then a little proven "growth" and the "for sale" sign will go up and that's where all hell breaks loose because neither Microsoft, Apple or Google can afford to let the other have Yahoo. It's not the value, but the Yahoo meat cleaver the buyer will have to use against the others. So $35 is in the bag; $40+ is more likely...and Marissa will jockey for a top position with the buyer (think CEO). And it won't just be these 3, but there will be others. So, the bidding war, which could have already begun (and there's reason to think so which I will not divulge here), should become headlines by end of this calendar year or certainly by this time next year. Never forget Dan Loeb is there.

Topic.Title: Yahoo Will Be Bought for Over $40 per Share After Alibaba IPO

Message.Msg: YES, the board needs private message capabilities, you're so right Thank you so much for such a detailed response. I have been thinking of which companies would be tops on Marissa's list. You hit the nail on the head with the fact that she would not want to be less than what she is now - CEO - perhaps with the exception of Apple - & even there Cook's position would not be stable with Marissa in the 'wings'. For this same reason I don't think it would be Google - there are other issues with Google as well. I can see it being Microsoft - Ballmer no longer has a steel grip on his position there perhaps Marissa CEO Ballmer Chairman. It's all conjecture, but it's certainly possible. I certainly don't forget that Loeb is there. I am wondering if Marissa will be named Chairman/woman/person? What are your thoughts on that?

Message.Msg: Thanks. Your question is a very good one. I sort of gave my answer to it in my reply to basketaetc1's post above before I read your message. $40 is possible. If it happens before the Alibaba IPO, and it could, then it's still off to the races, but I think the higher payoff for Yahoo investors comes in the steps I presented above. I like your posts, by the way. I try to see things through Loeb's prism as much as Marissa's.
